body.p: Agavi can be installed in several ways. The recommended way is to use PEAR, as it performs a complete setup for your system.

If you wish, you can install Agavi (and the Phing package on which the project configuration system depends) manually. A Subversion repository is also available. For full details on installation using these methods, please see (manual).
body.section:
From PEAR Installation with PEAR is relatively simple. Discover the Agavi PEAR channel and then install Agavi using the PEAR command line interface: $ pear channel-discover pear.agavi.org
Adding Channel "pear.agavi.org" succeeded Discovery of channel "pear.agavi.org" succeeded
$ pear install -a agavi/agavi.
Since Agavi 1.0.0 is still in a beta state, you may have to set your PEAR preferred package state to beta before installing Agavi:
$ pear config-set preferred_state beta

section.title: Testing your installation
section.p: A properly deployed Agavi installation enables the Agavi project configuration script, agavi. You should test that the installation worked correctly by executing agavi from the command line. This should provide some basic information about your current environment:

$ agavi Agavi > status:
[echo] PHP: [echo] Version: 5.2.6-2 [echo] Include path: .:/usr/share/php:/usr/share/pear [echo] [echo] Phing: [echo] Version: Phing version 2.3.1RC1 [echo] [echo] Agavi: [echo] Installation directory: /usr/share/php/agavi [echo] Version: 1.0.0-beta1 [echo] URL: http://www.agavi.org [echo] [echo] Project: [echo] (not found) [echo] [echo] For a list of possible build targets, call this script with the -l argument.
(Note that version information may differ slightly.) If you are getting errors instead, Agavi isn't installed or configured correctly. Since this often happens in broken and mishandled PHP installations, feel free to bug some other Agavi developers about it (see (getting help) for more details).
